channel.title: NASA TO NUKE MOON OMG
channel.description: I find this very interesting that they have found water molecules on the Moon. Since they found water on Mars first. [quote=NASA.gov] NASA scientists have discovered water molecules in the polar regions of the moon. Instruments aboard three separate spacecraft revealed water molecules in amounts that are greater than predicted, but still relatively small. Hydroxyl, a molecule consisting of one oxygen atom and one hydrogen atom, also was found in the lunar soil. The findings were published in Thursday's edition of the journal Science. [/quote] Original Source [b][url=https://www.nasa.gov/topics/moonmars/features/moon20090924.html]NASA.gov[/url][/b]

item.title: NASA TO NUKE MOON OMG
item.dc:creator: GordonReturns
item.description:
CTID:

You could always make a prison farm on the moon.

I’m a visionary. Ahead of my time.

Someonerandm:

Just like Hitler and his “prison farms”.

Huh? It would just be like the next Australia…but not as cool

danielsangeo:

By the time the Earth is swallowed by the sun (the original standard), it’ll be several billion years since humans disappeared from the universe. Just sayin’…

fix’d

item.title: NASA TO NUKE MOON OMG
item.dc:creator: danielsangeo
item.description:
Winged One:

Evolution comes out of necessity.

Perhaps, but I need the crab/spider legs and giant mouth filled with sharp teeth. And I need to destroy condiment jars with my mind.

Winged One:

Since technology gives all that we need, I don’t think a radical change is incoming, or at least not a very flattering one (see WALL-E).

The humans in Wall-E are only about 700 years in the future. By the time the Earth is swallowed by the sun (the original standard), it’ll be several billion years since humans appeared on the scene. Just sayin’…

Read full topic

Think about tits that never start to hang down, folks! :retard:

item.description:
TheeGoatPig:

And one third or one fifth the gravity (I can never remember which). That’s a big one that people always forget.

actually that would be pretty awesome IMO

even though jumping on a trampoline could cause you to leave the planet’s atmosphere :aah:

item.description:
If everyone finally realized religion is a kids bedtime story then maybe we’d have peace and we would be able to explore the universe!

item.title: NASA TO NUKE MOON OMG
item.dc:creator: TheeGoatPig
item.description:
Every human that you meet has 100 strands of mutated DNA from the last generation. It’s not much when compared to the billions of strands of DNA that we all have, but after a few million years it will add up. Assuming we don’t kill ourselves off in that time

item.title: NASA TO NUKE MOON OMG
item.dc:creator: raw_bean
item.description:
danielsangeo:

Another point is that, by the time the sun swallows the Earth, there would be no humans as we would’ve evolved beyond the Homo sapiens sapiens common ancestor into…something else.

Dark overlords of the universe, perhaps.

Not if we don’t manage to even colonise our nearest planetary bodies we won’t. Hence my point in favour of moon and Mars bases. We have our Dark Overlord destiny to rise to, after all.

Read full topic

danielsangeo:

Dark overlords of the universe, perhaps.

https://www.marvunapp.com/Appendix2/darkovrlrdhoward3.jpg

I was thinking more along the lines of…

As for colonising another planet, as said before, we’ll have to otherwise Earth will become overpopulated and will not be able to support us anymore.

AS for the topic, the water was detected on two previous missions, but the Indian sattelite confirmed it as far as I know.

item.title: NASA TO NUKE MOON OMG
item.dc:creator: raw_bean
item.description:
Regardless of all else, the sun swallowing the Earth is a dead cert, just not for a long time. Basically, through accident or the lifecycle of our own sun, there is no prospect for long-term survival of the human race on only one planet. (Of course, take the timeline far forward enough and we have the even bigger issue of the inevitability of entropy increasing and the eventual running out of new suns and solar systems to colonise, but we’ve got even more billions of years to worry about that one.)

The other point is that the resources and technological advances made to enable, or discovered as a result of, space exploration and colonisation will benefit our descendants.

Read full topic

item.description:
Mr.Shadow:

SPORE much?

Never played it.

Nosehole:

And then there is the fundamental issue of why you want to build a base on mars. What service does it serve that is so important that the money spend elsewhere would not do more?

The Human race will eventually have to colonize Mars in order to sustain its own survival. Do you know nothing?
